titleproper.value: Guide to the Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives Printed Ephemera Collection on the Labour Party (Great Britain) <num>PE.034</num>

publisher.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

addressline: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

creation.value: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace <date>2018-08-22T20:42:03</date>

corpname.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

unittitle.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives Printed Ephemera Collection on the Labour Party (Great Britain)

abstract.value: The Tamiment Library, New York University, founded in 1906 as the library of the Rand School of Social Science, is a special collection documenting the history of United States radicalism, labor, and progressive social action. It accumulated this artificial collection of printed ephemera gradually over the years. The Printed Ephemera Collection on the Labour Party (Great Britain) consists of fliers, newspaper clippings, reports, pamphlets, publications, and other printed ephemera.

p.value: Published citations should take the following form: <lb/><lb/>Identification of item, date; Collection name; Collection number; box number; folder number; <lb/>Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives <lb/>Elmer Holmes Bobst Library <lb/>70 Washington Square South <lb/>New York, NY 10012, New York University Libraries.
Materials in this collection have been compiled by the Tamiment Library. There is no accession record associated with this collection.
The Labour party came to power for the first time in 1924 and again in 1929.  The party survives today as one of the leading political parties in England.

The collection documents activities and events of the British Labour Party from 1910 and on.  The collection consists of memoranda, newspaper clippings, convention materials, and constitutions, as well as a pamphlets and publications.
